articles.headline: Stuttgart Struggles to House the Migrants It Embraces
articles.snippet: Migration has long been an engine of growth for the German city, and integration the bedrock of civic pride. But problems include a dearth of affordable housing.
articles.abstract: Migration has long been an engine of growth for the German city, and integration the bedrock of civic pride. But problems include a dearth of affordable housing.
articles.lead_paragraph: STUTTGART, Germany — With arson attacks on refugee camps and resistance from Chancellor Angela Merkel’s own political partners, it’s not hard to find doomsayers predicting trouble for German cities absorbing asylum seekers. But in this peaceful and pragmatic city, synonymous with German know-how and corporate giants like Bosch, Porsche and Mercedes, it is possible to glimpse something else: a rosier future.

articles.headline: U.S. to Release 6,000 Inmates From Prisons
articles.snippet: The release, scheduled to start at the end of the month, will be one of the largest one-time discharges of federal inmates in American history, officials said.
articles.abstract: The release, scheduled to start at the end of the month, will be one of the largest one-time discharges of federal inmates in American history, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is preparing to release roughly 6,000 inmates from federal prisons starting at the end of this month as part of an effort to ease overcrowding and roll back the harsh penalties given to nonviolent drug dealers in the 1980s and ’90s, according to federal law enforcement officials.

articles.headline: What an ISIS Chemical Strike Did to One Syrian Family
articles.snippet: The residents of the town of Marea had already survived crackdowns, tanks, infantry attacks, airstrikes and cluster munitions. But something about an attack this summer was different.
articles.abstract: The residents of the town of Marea had already survived crackdowns, tanks, infantry attacks, airstrikes and cluster munitions. But something about an attack this summer was different.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — The warning from the front lines came by walkie-talkie. An Islamic State artillery position had boomed to the east, signaling that an incoming round was whistling toward Marea, a town on northern Syria’s agricultural flatland.

articles.headline: For Government That Works, Call In the Auditors
articles.snippet: Studies of a federal initiative to “weatherize” homes suggest that an impartial view is needed in order to evaluate such programs.
articles.abstract: Studies of a federal initiative to “weatherize” homes suggest that an impartial view is needed in order to evaluate such programs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Environmental regulators in Gujarat, one of India’s fastest-growing industrial states, found themselves in an implausible situation a few years ago: Every single city breached national air quality standards. And yet environmental audits kept finding that factories met pollution limits.

articles.headline: Test Scores Under Common Core Show That ‘Proficient’ Varies by State
articles.snippet: For tests given last spring under the new Common Core requirements, the description of the results comes down to the different labels each state uses to describe the exact same scores on the same tests.
articles.abstract: For tests given last spring under the new Common Core requirements, the description of the results comes down to the different labels each state uses to describe the exact same scores on the same tests.
articles.lead_paragraph: COLUMBUS, Ohio — Ohio seems to have taken a page from Lake Wobegon, where all the children are above average.

articles.headline: Volkswagen Sought a Green Seal for Its Diesel Cars
articles.snippet: Behind the scenes, Volkswagen’s main complaint involved the diesel engines it is accused of rigging, according to a former official at the Environmental Protection Agency.
articles.abstract: Behind the scenes, Volkswagen’s main complaint involved the diesel engines it is accused of rigging, according to a former official at the Environmental Protection Agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In July 2011, President Obama took the stage here to announce sweeping new fuel economy and carbon emissions targets for vehicles in the United States. Joining him were top executives from nearly every automaker, representing 90 percent of vehicles sold domestically.

articles.headline: Teamsters’ Pension Fund Warns 400,000 of Cuts
articles.snippet: If the reorganization of the Central States Pension Fund ultimately proves successful, it could serve as a model for other retirement plans with seemingly intractable financial problems.
articles.abstract: If the reorganization of the Central States Pension Fund ultimately proves successful, it could serve as a model for other retirement plans with seemingly intractable financial problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: A prominent Teamsters pension fund, one of the largest, has filed for reorganization under a new federal law and has sent letters to more than 400,000 members warning that their benefits must be cut.

articles.headline: For Jason Chaffetz, Quixotic House Speaker Bid Is in Character
articles.snippet: When support for Representative Kevin McCarthy began to crack, Mr. Chaffetz ran a familiar play: Talk about love of country and prepare for the live shot.
articles.abstract: When support for Representative Kevin McCarthy began to crack, Mr. Chaffetz ran a familiar play: Talk about love of country and prepare for the live shot.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Jason Chaffetz of Utah admits he is not the best candidate to become speaker of the House. He fully expects to lose when his Republican colleagues pick their nominee on Thursday. But opportunity for Mr. Chaffetz is like the scent of an airport Cinnabon, and he has a habit of racing to its smell.

articles.headline: Doubts Circle Viacom, Vanguard of Yesteryear
articles.snippet: Viacom’s stock is off 37 percent this year, and it faces lower TV ratings, weak ad sales and a lackluster film slate. The shift has been dramatic.
articles.abstract: Viacom’s stock is off 37 percent this year, and it faces lower TV ratings, weak ad sales and a lackluster film slate. The shift has been dramatic.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a bleak day in early August at the Times Square headquarters of Viacom, the company that is the home of MTV, Nickelodeon, Comedy Central and Paramount’s film studios. Weak earnings led shares in the media conglomerate to plunge as much as 22 percent in trading before closing down 14 percent for the day, wiping out billions of dollars in market value.

articles.headline: Waves of Young Syrian Men Bring Hope, and a Test, to Europe
articles.snippet: The exodus deprives Syria of a demographic crucial to reconstruction while threatening to create a new underclass in Europe.
articles.abstract: The exodus deprives Syria of a demographic crucial to reconstruction while threatening to create a new underclass in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: LESBOS, Greece — When the conflict in Syria began more than four years ago, Mustafa Alabi was a 17-year-old soccer whiz who had quit high school to sew clothes in his father’s workshop.

articles.headline: Friends of the S.S. United States Send Out a Last S.O.S.
articles.snippet: Admirers are racing to save the supership, once the world’s fastest oceanliner. Ideas include making it a floating hotel in New York City.
articles.abstract: Admirers are racing to save the supership, once the world’s fastest oceanliner. Ideas include making it a floating hotel in New York City.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Titanic-sized supership that once ferried presidents, Hollywood royalty, actual royalty and even the Mona Lisa has a place in the history books as the fastest oceanliner in the world. The owners are now racing to avoid having the ship, the S.S. United States, relegated to the junk heap.

articles.headline: Volkswagen U.S. Chief Knew of Potential Emissions Problems in 2014
articles.snippet: Michael Horn, the chief executive of Volkswagen Group of America, is expected to apologize for the company’s trickery before Congress on Thursday.
articles.abstract: Michael Horn, the chief executive of Volkswagen Group of America, is expected to apologize for the company’s trickery before Congress on Thursday.
articles.lead_paragraph: The head of Volkswagen’s American business knew about a potential emissions problem with the company’s vehicles in spring 2014, earlier than previously acknowledged by top management in the United States.
articles.byline: By Danielle Ivory and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Russian Cruise Missiles Help Syrians Go on the Offensive
articles.snippet: The Russian-backed ground offensive followed a missile assault, reflecting what one official called a new phase of the Syria alliance.
articles.abstract: The Russian-backed ground offensive followed a missile assault, reflecting what one official called a new phase of the Syria alliance.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Russia and Syria unleashed a coordinated assault by land, air and sea on Wednesday, seeking to reverse recent gains by rebel groups that were beginning to encroach on the Syrian coast, a critical bastion of power for President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.byline: By Anne Barnard and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Common Response After Killings in Oregon: ‘I Want to Have a Gun’
articles.snippet: While President Obama has called for stricter gun regulations, many in the Roseburg, Ore., community said the shooting rampage had only increased their belief in the importance of owning guns.
articles.abstract: While President Obama has called for stricter gun regulations, many in the Roseburg, Ore., community said the shooting rampage had only increased their belief in the importance of owning guns.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROSEBURG, Ore. — A week has passed since J. J. Vicari huddled underneath a desk while gunshots exploded in the classroom next door. Now he is thinking about guns. Not about tightening gun laws, as President Obama urged after nine people were killed at the community college here. But about buying one for himself.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Julie Turkewitz
